explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — This is a macro used to obtain sock_impl and conn_impl. Its expansion could contain expressions, function calls, or even loop constructs; inspect it to ensure it does not introduce a for loop or side-effects that would affect any for-clause analysis.

OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS — Macro invoked at the end of the function. Its expansion may invoke functions or contain control structures (including for loops). Must be checked to ensure no for loops or modifications of potential loop counters/flags that could change the MISRA analysis.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — Frequently used by object-table macros (and shown in the static graph). If OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET expands to call this, its implementation must be inspected for any for loops or side-effecting behavior that could be relevant to the MISRA for-loop rule.

OS_SelectSingle_Impl — Called when sock_impl->selectable is true. While the target function does not contain an explicit for loop, macros or inlineable code could hide loops; also if a for loop existed that called this function in its body, the behaviour of called functions is part of the for-loop body under the MISRA rule, so inspect this function for loops/side effects.

OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl — Shown in the static call graph as associated with setting socket flags; the macro OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS may invoke this. Inspect its body for for loops or modifications to objects that could be used as loop counters or flags.

OS_impl_file_internal_record_t — Type definition (structure) for sock_impl/conn_impl. Inspect member definitions (selectable, fd, etc.) to ensure they are plain members and not defined via macros or inline functions that could introduce loops or alter semantics relevant to for-loop well-formedness.

OS_SockAddr_t — Type of Addr. Its definition (ActualLength, AddrData) must be checked to ensure member access does not expand to macros or inline code containing loops or side-effects that would affect MISRA analysis.

accept — The POSIX accept() call is invoked; although a library call, it could be a macro or wrapper in this codebase. Verify its definition/wrapper to ensure it does not expand to code containing for loops or modify objects that could serve as loop counters/flags.
